sentence: Shares of Red Hat (RHT) have been red hot so far in 2018, rising 26% year to date, compared with a more than 1% decline in the S&P 500 index.
And if you’ve owned the shares over the past 52 weeks, you’re up a whopping 82%, while the S&P has risen just 12% during that span.
The Linux and Cloud software provider is set to report fourth quarter fiscal 2018 earnings results after the closing bell Monday.

And Wall Street, which has assigned a consensus Buy rating on the stock, expects strong results for the company, especially in light of the better-than-expected Cloud results just released from the likes of Adobe (ADBE) and Salesforce (CRM).
For the quarter that ended February, Wall Street expects the Raleigh, NC-based company to deliver earnings of 81 cents per share on revenue of $761.6 million.
This compares to the year-ago quarter when earnings were 61 cents per share on revenue of $628.84 million.
For the full year, earnings are projected to rise 26% year over year to $2.87 per share, while full-year revenue of $2.91 billion would rise 20.6% year over year.
As robust as these numbers would appear, they underestimate Red Hat’s capabilities, both in the near term and long term.

In the third quarter, during which it beat on both the top and bottom lines, the company grew earnings 20% year over year to 73 cents per share, while revenues increased 21.6% year over year to almost $748 million, driven by strong demand for its hybrid cloud solutions.
The management parlayed that by raising Q4 revenue guidance from $758 million to $763 million, compared to (then) consensus of $748.9 million.
Meanwhile, EPS guidance was boosted to 81 cents, above (then) consensus of 75 cents.

Growth is being driven by a combination of factors, including breakthrough innovations such as such as OpenShift — its container platform component — and its RHEL platform (Red Hat Enterprise Linux)— its software-as-a-service suite for managing application servers and data storage — which are helping Red Hat to deliver not only stronger subscription revenues, but also better profit margins.
The company also is benefiting from its strong corporate partnerships forged with Fortune 500 titans such as IBM (IBM), Amazon (AMZN), Google (GOOG , GOOGL) and Microsoft (MSFT), to name a few.
And given as an example, Red Hat’s recent cloud collaboration deal with Alibaba (BABA), the company is well-positioned for significant double-digit revenue growth rates in the years to come.
Red Hat earnings are predicted to grow at more than 16% annually in the next two years, while revenue is projected to grow at an average rate of 18% over the next five years.
This means despite stiff competition it faces from the likes of Citrix (CTXS) and VMware (VMW), Red Hat stock won’t be impeded.
So, while the shares — at 45 times 2019 estimates — are not bargains, the stock should continue to deliver above-average returns, reaching $180, or 20%, in the next 12 to 18 months.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
